<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[48, 62, 547, 77]]<|/det|>
1 Fig. 1.1 shows two identical cylindrical metal conductors \(P\) and \(Q\), each of length \(L\) and cross-sectional area \(A\).

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[95, 99, 497, 262]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[278, 279, 317, 294]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[71, 306, 548, 319]]<|/det|>
The conductors are placed parallel to each other. The perpendicular distance from the midpoint of P to point X is \(p\). The perpendicular distance from the midpoint of Q to point X is \(q\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[71, 344, 547, 358]]<|/det|>
The two conductors are electrically connected in parallel. This parallel combination is connected in series to a power supply and a resistor. The potential difference \(V\) between the ends of \(P\) is the

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[71, 371, 346, 384]]<|/det|>
same as the potential difference between the ends of Q.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[71, 396, 427, 410]]<|/det|>
The magnetic flux density at \(X\) due to the currents in the conductors is \(B\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[71, 422, 338, 437]]<|/det|>
It is suggested that \(B\) is related to \(p\) by the relationship

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[255, 441, 341, 468]]<|/det|>
\[
B=\frac{Y A V}{L p}+\frac{Y Z A V}{L q}
\]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[71, 475, 216, 488]]<|/det|>
where \(Y\) and \(Z\) are constants.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[71, 500, 413, 515]]<|/det|>
Plan a laboratory experiment to test the relationship between \(B\) and \(p\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[71, 526, 372, 541]]<|/det|>
Draw a diagram showing the arrangement of your equipment.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[71, 552, 417, 567]]<|/det|>
Explain how the results could be used to determine values for \(Y\) and \(Z\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[71, 579, 228, 593]]<|/det|>
In your plan you should include:

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[71, 605, 234, 619]]<|/det|>
- the procedure to be followed

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[71, 632, 244, 644]]<|/det|>
- the measurements to be taken

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[71, 656, 206, 669]]<|/det|>
- the control of variables

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[71, 682, 210, 697]]<|/det|>
- the analysis of the data

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[71, 709, 266, 723]]<|/det|>
- any safety precautions to be taken.

2 A student investigates the cooling of a liquid in a beaker.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[71, 89, 422, 104]]<|/det|>
The temperature \(\theta_{\mathrm{R}}\) of the laboratory is measured using a thermometer.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[71, 115, 382, 128]]<|/det|>
Hot water is added to an insulated beaker, as shown in Fig. 2.1.

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[148, 139, 448, 344]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[278, 355, 317, 369]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[71, 382, 547, 396]]<|/det|>
The thermometer measures the temperature of the water. At time \(t\) the temperature of the water is \(\theta\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[71, 421, 271, 435]]<|/det|>
A series of readings of \(t\) and \(\theta\) are taken.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[71, 447, 336, 461]]<|/det|>
It is suggested that \(\theta\) and \(t\) are related by the equation

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[243, 472, 353, 492]]<|/det|>
\[
\theta=\theta_{\mathrm{R}}+\left(\theta_{0}-\theta_{\mathrm{R}}\right) \mathrm{e}^{-\left(\frac{t}{k}\right)}
\]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[71, 503, 345, 517]]<|/det|>
where \(\theta_{0}\) is the temperature at \(t=0\) and \(K\) is a constant.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[71, 528, 422, 544]]<|/det|>
(a) A graph is plotted of \(\ln \left(\theta-\theta_{\mathrm{R}}\right)\) on the \(y\)-axis against \(t\) on the \(x\)-axis.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[94, 554, 364, 568]]<|/det|>
Determine expressions for the gradient and \(y\)-intercept.

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[283, 709, 352, 752]]<|/det|>
\[
\begin{array}{r}
\text { gradient }= \\
y \text {-intercept }=
\end{array}
\]
